author: By Liz Day and Rachel Abrams
title: Filings Show Continuing Battle Over Britney Spears’s Finances
description: New court documents reveal a heated exchange between Ms. Spears’s lawyers and the former business manager of her estate.
content: For more than a month, Britney Spears’s lawyer has been making demands that the former business manager of her estate hand over basic financial information as part of an examination of the nearly 14 years of her conservatorship. Lawyers for the firm have largely refused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Do You Think We Need to Change the Way Math Is Taught?
description: Proposed guidelines in California recommend an overhaul for math education. What do you think?
content: Do you like math? Do you think your teachers have done a good job in teaching you math over the years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Summer Walker Beats Abba’s First Album in Decades to No. 1
description: The Atlanta R&B singer’s “Still Over It” becomes her first LP to top the Billboard 200, with the equivalent of 166,000 sales in the United States.
content: When Abba, whose classic songs like “Dancing Queen” and “Take a Chance on Me” are the epitome of Europop ear candy, announced in September that it would be returning this fall with its first studio album in 40 years, it was assumed that the new release would be an immediate blockbuster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: What New Yorkers Need to Know About Tornadoes
description: While the chances of a tornado in any of the boroughs are slim, experts said one could still spawn from a severe thunderstorm and devastate the city.
content: Air twisted, whirled and howled, hurling debris off brownstone rooftops and shucking trees from sidewalk plots. Cars flipped, people fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Simple as Water’ and the American Music Awards
description: HBO airs a documentary about families affected by the civil war in Syria. And Cardi B hosts the 2021 American Music Awards on ABC.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: What the Metaverse Sounds Like to Hans Zimmer
description: The composer discusses how streaming and A.I. are transforming movie music.
content: Hans Zimmer has spent his career scoring cinematic worlds, from the ancient Rome of “Gladiator” to the futuristic landscape of “Dune.” So what does the metaverse sound like to him? “It sounds like just some giant, horrible, dehumanizing mess right now,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Luke Vander Ploeg, Daniel Guillemette, Clare Toeniskoetter, Larissa Anderson, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How the U.S. Hid a Deadly Airstrike
description: Inside the Times Investigation on a bombing that killed dozens of noncombatants in Syria — one of the largest civilian casualty events of the war against the Islamic State.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: A Maori tribe tells anti-vaccine protesters to stop performing their haka.
description: Ngati Toa, which owns the legal rights to the dance, said it supports Covid vaccinations as the best chance to protect a group that has suffered disproportionally from pandemics.
content: At demonstrations against pandemic restrictions last week in Wellington, the New Zealand capital, some protesters performed the ceremonial Maori dance known as the Ka Mate haka, known internationally for its performance before rugby games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden and Xi meet amid economic and military tensions.
description: U.S. officials said the virtual summit on Monday was intended to reassure both sides that misunderstandings would not lead to unintended clashes.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met in a virtual summit on Monday evening as the United States seeks to engage in what the administration calls “intense competition” with China while preventing serious conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Christopher Flavelle and Alan Rappeport
title: Here’s what’s in the infrastructure bill that Biden signed today.
description: In total, the measure contains $550 billion in new funds to be spread around different areas of need.
content: Federal and state officials have identified priority projects that have been put off for years and may now move ahead as a result of the $1 trillion infrastructure bill that President Biden signed into law on Monday, such as repairing hundreds of aging bridges and building dozens of new or extended rail lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: With Gas Prices High, Calls Grow to Tap Strategic Oil Reserve
description: President Biden is under pressure to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Here’s how it works, and how it might lower prices (modestly, and maybe not for long).
content: As gasoline prices and inflationary pressures have climbed in recent weeks, calls have been growing in Congress for the Biden administration to tap into the nation’s Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Bad Could California’s Winter Coronavirus Surge Get?
description: After falling since late summer, coronavirus cases in the state have begun to tick up.
content: As you probably remember, the winter coronavirus surge in California last year was nothing short of catastrophic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 10 in the N.F.L.
description: Mac Jones is leading the Patriots back into the A.F.C.’s elite and Tom Brady and the Buccaneers are winless so far this November.
content: Each year, the N.F.L.’s draft generates needless hype around the selection of college athletes into the pros, turning most all observers into pseudo-general managers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Herrington
title: Spring Date Set for Broadway Revival of ‘For Colored Girls’
description: Ntozake Shange’s choreopoem begins performances in March at the Booth Theater, home to the original 1976 production.
content: The previously announced Broadway production of Ntozake Shange’s 1976 “for colored girls who have considered suicide/when the rainbow is enuf,” directed by Camille A. Brown, now has an opening date. After beginning previews on March 4, 2022, the show will open on March 24 at the Booth Theater, producers announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Steve Bannon turns himself in on contempt of Congress charges.
description: The former aide to President Donald J. Trump had refused to comply with a demand from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon, who served as a senior aide to President Donald J. Trump, surrendered to authorities and appeared in federal court on Monday, three days after he was indicted by a grand jury on two counts of contempt of Congress for refusing to provide information to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser, Ian Austen, Eduardo Medina and Jesus Jiménez
title: Hundreds Rescued After Landslides Pummel British Columbia
description: Helicopter search crews rescued people who had been trapped in their cars along highways. Heavy rainfall extended into nearby Washington State.
content: Hundreds of people were rescued from highways in British Columbia on Monday, officials said, after torrential rain set off landslides that trapped people in their cars and prompted evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Medusa’s Ankles,’ a Selection of A.S. Byatt’s Wildly Imagined Stories Across Three Decades
description: Byatt has been an articulate advocate for tapping the depths of fairy tales, but her stories tend to stay in realms of thinner altitude.
content: A.S. Byatt’s fiction, in the years since her best-selling and Booker Prize-winning novel “Possession” (1990), has been increasingly ornate, humorless, freighted with fantasy and myth, and encrusted with heavy literary reference. All my least favorite things in fiction, helpfully confined to one area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Inflation Will Make or Break the Next Spending Bill
description: President Biden is set to sign $1 trillion in infrastructure spending into law. But rising prices will determine what happens to his social bill.
content: Later today, President Biden is expected to sign into law the $1 trillion infrastructure spending bill, aimed at upgrading American roads, bridges, broadband internet and more. But the fate of the White House’s other economic priority — its $1.8 trillion social spending plan — remains cloudy amid intensifying concerns over inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google executives tell employees it can compete for Pentagon contracts without violating its principles.
description: The company abandoned work on an earlier military program after employees revolted.
content: Google executives told employees last week in a companywide meeting that it is interested in a Pentagon contract for cloud computing and that working for the military would not necessarily conflict with principles created by the company for how its artificial intelligence technology would be used.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones Loses by Default in Remaining Sandy Hook Defamation Suits
description: A Connecticut judge’s ruling against the Infowars host combines with decisions in Texas to grant a clean sweep for the families of 10 shooting victims.
content: WASHINGTON — A state court in Connecticut granted a sweeping victory to the families of eight people killed in a 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., who had sued the far-right broadcaster and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and his Infowars media outlet for defamation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: The Consulting Firm Billionaires Turn to When They Give Away Money
description: A little-known organization called the Bridgespan Group is guiding the philanthropic choices of many leading donors, including MacKenzie Scott.
content: MacKenzie Scott stepped out of the long shadow of her former husband, the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, by handing out billions of dollars in grants over the past two years to charities, community colleges, food banks and progressive nonprofits led by people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: A New Source of Fuel in an Aging Japan: Adult Incontinence
description: Waste from adult diapers is growing by tens of thousands of tons a year in Japan. One town may have a solution: recycle it into fuel pellets.
content: HOUKI, Japan — The restorative waters that flow into the public baths in this town near the coast of western Japan originate from hot springs more than two-thirds of a mile below ground. At the surface, before the water bubbles out of the spouts, it is further heated to 107 degrees Fahrenheit — an ideal temperature for cleansing and soaking weary muscles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 3, Episode 5: Imaginary Dead Cat Bounce
description: The problem with staking everything on one imposing figurehead is that eventually they get old and senile.
content: There was a moment in last week’s episode of “Succession” when Kendall was standing on Josh Aaronson’s patio, reminding Josh of their longtime friendship and boasting about his upcoming birthday party — acting like a big shot, in other words. Kendall had come to the meeting to show he could be the commanding, charismatic figure to lead Waystar into the future. And for a few seconds at least, he had his host’s undivided attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden to Bar New Drilling Around a Major Native American Cultural Site
description: After years of tribal requests, the president plans to block new oil and gas leases within 10 miles of Chaco Canyon in New Mexico. The move generated strong pushback from industry groups.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced on Monday that his administration was moving to block new federal oil and gas leasing within a 10-mile radius around Chaco Canyon in New Mexico, one of the nation’s oldest and most culturally significant Native American sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Why Don’t We Have a Covid Vaccine for Pets?
description: Scientists have developed vaccines for cats and dogs, but vaccinating companion animals is not necessary, experts said.
content: Over the past year, coronavirus vaccines have gone into billions of human arms — and into the fuzzy haunches of an ark’s worth of zoo animals. Jaguars are getting the jab. Bonobos are being dosed. So are orangutans and otters, ferrets and fruit bats, and, of course, lions and tigers and bears (oh, my!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: How to Feed the Hungry While Helping Struggling Restaurants Survive
description: A New Jersey program that partners nonprofit organizations with restaurants is helping people and small businesses stay afloat during the pandemic.
content: After lining a kitchen utility table with rows of food trays, the team members of MadeMeals, a meal prep service in Kearny, N.J., take their next steps with caution and speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith, Neil MacFarquhar, Tim Arango, Chloe Reynolds, Adria Malcolm, Mason Trinca, Cydni Elledge and Stephen Speranza
title: Four Lives Lost: Inside America’s Homicide Surge
description: In many cities, towns and rural areas, homicides are up in 2021, even after a sharp rise last year. The reasons are elusive. The impact is immeasurable. Here are four stories from one month that offer a glimpse of the toll.
content: A hot dog vendor walking out of a downtown ballpark, where gunfire pierced the night after the home team won a game. A woman whose quarrel with a trusted friend took a heartbreaking turn. A young man caught up in drugs passing through a shabby motel. A new mother shot by a stranger in a random act of extreme violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball Gets Another Chance to Honor a Legend
description: Minnie Miñoso was a pioneering Black Latino star in the 1950s whose greatness and impact have been overlooked by Hall of Famer voters. That may finally change.
content: Minnie Miñoso was a mentor for generations of Chicago White Sox players. He served many years as a player and a coach, lived year-round in the city and upheld the team’s tradition as a welcoming place for Cuban stars. He liked to offer this advice:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Covid Thanksgiving, Round 2
description: How health experts are thinking about the holidays.
content: When I injured my knee a few years ago, it was something of a crisis. I canceled plans and stayed home. When I did venture out, I used crutches and a knee brace. Today, my knee isn’t perfect, but it doesn’t hold me back. I’ve just accepted that I have to do things a little differently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Adele, Dressed for Power
description: The gown Adele wore for her ‘One Night Only’ concert was fit for a diva, but the white pantsuit she wore for her Oprah interview made an even stronger statement.
content: As the re-emergence of Adele continues with the one-two punch of an Oprah Winfrey interview and a “One Night Only” concert at the Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles in front of a starry, starry crowd — all in prelude to an album release on Friday — so, too, does her mastery of the art the image; her message of post-divorce strength and freedom as told through every performative tool at her disposal. Including her lyrics, her interview and (yes) her clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Whose Writing Is on the Wall at the Museum? It Could Be Yours.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about new museum practices to make the curation and interpretation of art more inclusive. Then, they will write their own artistic responses to a piece of artwork.
content: Featured Article: “Whose Writing Is on the Wall at the Museum? It Could Be Yours.” by Julia Jacobs
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Hochschild
title: A Landmark Reckoning With America’s Racial Past and Present
description: Originally published as a series in The New York Times Magazine and now revised and expanded as a book, “The 1619 Project,” edited by Nikole Hannah-Jones, Caitlin Roper, Ilena Silverman and Jake Silverstein, undertakes an ambitious examination of slavery and its ongoing legacy for Black Americans.
content: THE 1619 PROJECTA New Origin StoryEdited by Nikole Hannah-Jones, Caitlin Roper, Ilena Silverman and Jake Silverstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Risk-Return Trade-Off Is Phony
description: A new book says the strongest long-term returns come from reducing the risk in a portfolio.
content: Conventional wisdom in investing says there’s a trade-off between risk and return. To make a lot of money, you must take the chance of big losses. Play it safe and you’ll most likely have to settle for meager returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in California
description: A storybook home in Oakland, a midcentury-modern house in Sierra Madre and a 1947 ranch-style retreat in Santa Cruz.
content: This storybook house was designed by Walter W. Dixon, an architect who designed several other homes on the block, as well. It is within walking distance of College Avenue, the area’s main thoroughfare, where there are two large grocery stores, a Chicago-style pizza restaurant, a gastro pub and a See’s Candies shop. It is also an easy walk to the Rockridge BART station, where the train carries passengers into San Francisco in about 30 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Austria’s new lockdown applies only to the unvaccinated.
description: The restrictions were among the toughest of a wave of new rules in Europe, which the W.H.O. has said is “back at the epicenter of the pandemic.”
content: Unvaccinated Austrians ages 12 and older awoke on Monday morning confined to their homes for all but essential activities, as one of the strictest coronavirus lockdowns in Europe went into effect to battle a surge in infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: His Reasons for Opposing Trump Were Biblical. Now a Top Christian Editor Is Out.
description: A clash over culture and politics comes to World, a groundbreaking journalistic institution that covers evangelical Christians.
content: When Marvin Olasky gets angry emails from readers — more often than not about an exposé of wrongdoing at an evangelical church, or about a story that reflects poorly on Donald Trump — he has a stock reply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cruet for Dressing or Syrup
description: These borosilicate glass vessels from Hungary are an attractive accompaniment to the dinner table.
content: These well-designed cruets from Civilian Objects, a company created by Nicko Elliott and Ksenia Kagner of the New York design studio Civilian, make a fine house gift or handy accessory. While they are intended for oil or vinegar, or a combination, they also beg to be filled with maple syrup for a holiday breakfast because the design that makes them so suitable for oil applies to syrup as well. They have an elegant spout, a collar to catch any drips and a textured etched finish for the stopper to prevent leaking. Made of borosilicate glass, a material that was created for laboratory equipment, they’re produced in Hungary by Trendglas Jena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Underdog No More, a Deaf Football Team Takes California by Storm
description: The California School for the Deaf, Riverside, is steamrolling its opponents, electrifying a campus that has seen more than a few athletic defeats.
content: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The athletic program at the California School for the Deaf, Riverside, has suffered its share of humiliations and harassment over the years. There was the time that a visiting team’s volleyball coach mocked the deaf players. And another time a hearing coach for the girls’ basketball team listened as opponents discussed how embarrassing it would be to lose to a deaf team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Jin Yu Young
title: India reopens to vaccinated travelers as more Asian countries loosen travel rules.
description: The Indian government announced on Monday that it would allow vaccinated foreign visitors into the country for the first time in more than 20 months, delivering a boost to a battered tourism industry as coronavirus cases ease and vaccinations pick up across Asia.
content: The Indian government announced on Monday that it would allow vaccinated foreign visitors into the country for the first time in more than 20 months, delivering a boost to a battered tourism industry as coronavirus cases ease and vaccinations pick up across Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Biden and Xi meet to keep “communication lines open.”
content: President Biden and the Chinese leader Xi Jinping are having their third conversation in 10 months in an effort to keep “communication lines open” and avoid military action as tensions escalate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood crew union narrowly ratifies its contracts with studios.
description: The margin was perilously narrow, with many International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees members viewing the pact as toothless in terms of preventing long working hours.
content: Camera operators, prop makers, lighting technicians and other members of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees ratified new contracts with Hollywood studios on Monday. But the margin was perilously narrow, with many members viewing the pact as toothless in terms of preventing long working hours — the kind of conditions recently endured on the set of “Rust,” the Alec Baldwin movie where the cinematographer was killed and the director wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: College Student Charged in Arson at Texas Synagogue
description: Security footage of the attack on Halloween night showed the man carrying a five-gallon fuel jug and a roll of toilet paper to the synagogue’s entrance, the F.B.I. said.
content: An 18-year-old college student was charged with arson on Monday in an attack on a synagogue in Austin, Texas, on Halloween night that caused extensive damage to the building, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael O'Loughlin
title: Pope Francis Sent Me a Letter. It Gives Me Hope as a Gay Catholic.
description: Dialogue may be possible between L.G.B.T. Catholics and church leaders, even at the highest levels.
content: When Carol Baltosiewich was a Catholic nun, she spent 10 years caring for young men dying from AIDS. Even so, the first time I spoke to her, in 2016, I was terrified to tell her I’m gay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Breads Bakery Brings Its Babka to the Upper East Side
description: The bakery is adding a black and white cookie to this location, along with a marble rye.
content: Gradually, Breads Bakery has been expanding beyond its original 2013 flagship near Union Square, with locations near Lincoln Center and a kiosk in Bryant Park. Its latest addition is on the Upper East Side, opening Friday, in the space that was occupied by Maison Kayser on Third Avenue, with an airy, open floor plan and the baking in full view. Opening just before Thanksgiving, with several new items for the holiday like sweet potato rolls and a lemon ricotta pie, this new Breads will also be selling its pecan tart, savory squash tart and harvest babka (made with roasted sweet potatoes, onions and cheese). Nodding to some neighborhood specialties, the bakery has added an excellent marble rye bread made with upstate winter rye, and created its own version of a black and white cookie, often credited to Glaser’s, now gone from Yorkville, with a veneer of puff pastry enclosing a caky filling that’s both chocolate and vanilla. Salads and soups are sold, and sandwiches and spreads are coming soon. There is outdoor seating. In the spring the company will add a branch in Rockefeller Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: When the Next Thing You Know Is That You Have Covid
description: The future of the virus — and violence — in America.
content: Bret Stephens: Hello from Covid quarantine, Gail, breakthrough-case edition. It’s been six months since my second shot of Moderna, and — presto! — I got it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tong Zhao
title: Why Is China Building Up Its Nuclear Arsenal?
description: Without U.S. and Chinese willingness to enter a clear dialogue, the results could be catastrophic.
content: BEIJING — Forget about nuclear might. It’s time for the United States to talk to China about mutual vulnerability.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Crunch at Ports Spells Trouble for U.S. Farms
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 15, 2021.
content: “This is not just a problem, it’s not just an inconvenience, it’s catastrophic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Taiwan, Trade, Tech and More: A Tense Era in U.S.-China Ties
description: The Biden administration has called managing America’s relationship with Beijing “the biggest geopolitical test of the 21st century.”
content: [Follow live updates on the upcoming meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: First Asian American Muppet Arrives on ‘Sesame Street’
description: Ji-Young, a guitar-playing Korean American character, will bring rock music and conversations about racism to the long-running children’s show starting on Thanksgiving Day.
content: “Sesame Street” is welcoming its first Asian American muppet to the neighborhood. Ji-Young, a Korean American 7-year-old who loves playing her electric guitar and skateboarding, will make her debut next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: If Remote Work Empties Downtowns, Can Theaters Fill Their Seats?
description: Since the pandemic, San Francisco has embraced work-from-home policies. Now venues and concert halls are wondering if weeknight audiences are a thing of the past.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — As live performance finally returns after the pandemic shutdown, cultural institutions are confronting a long list of unknowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 12 Wines for Thanksgiving and Beyond
description: The characteristics that make a bottle great for the holiday work for just about any occasion. These wines not only taste good, they feel good.
content: Thanksgiving is the most singular meal of the year for most Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Bridge and Road Repairs Ahead, but Where?
description: How will money from the infrastructure bill be spent? State and local officials have their wish lists.
content: It’s Monday. We’ll look at what the infrastructure bill will mean for New York. We’ll also look at new delicatessens that are designed to look old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell proposes a shift to Britain, dropping ‘Royal Dutch’ from its name.
description: The restructuring is meant to make the company more appealing to investors and make it easier to sell assets, the oil giant said.
content: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, said Monday that it was proposing to move its headquarters to Britain from the Netherlands and make major changes in its share ownership and tax status, including dropping “Royal Dutch” from its name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: With Halo Infinite, Microsoft Hopes to Rekindle Its Flagship Game
description: Though interest in Halo has waned over the years, the company is banking on a new version to goose sales of its Xbox and subscription gaming service.
content: When Microsoft released its first Xbox console 20 years ago, executives did not think that Halo, a new game set in a 26th-century galactic war pitting humans against alien invaders, would become the face of the tech giant’s gaming aspirations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: How America’s Pandemic Economic Response Fought the Last War
description: A focus on the challenges of the Great Recession has fueled some of the challenges of this crisis.
content: It was the early 2010s. The global financial crisis had become the stuff of history books, and the recession it had caused was long over. But the United States economy was still haunted by a series of chronic, interrelated problems: too little spending by consumers and businesses; too few jobs; and too-low inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Hilton
title: Inside the Struggle to Save Bulgaria’s Last Narrow-Gauge Railroad
description: The Rhodope Narrow-Gauge Railway serves remote communities in southwestern Bulgaria. Can longtime riders — and young enthusiasts — keep it running?
content: Dressed in a floral-patterned tunic and baggy pants, her hair covered with a colorful head scarf, Sabie Djikova loaded a dozen bottles — 45 pounds’ worth of milk — into a knapsack and a handmade bag, heaved them over her narrow shoulders and headed down the unpaved road toward the nearby train station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Names Mitch Landrieu to Oversee Infrastructure Spending
description: Mr. Landrieu, a former mayor of New Orleans, will supervise the distribution of funds from the bipartisan legislation that the president will sign into law on Monday.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Sunday night named Mitch Landrieu, a former mayor of New Orleans and a former lieutenant governor of Louisiana, to oversee $1 trillion in infrastructure spending from the bipartisan legislation that the president will sign into law on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Planning for Surgery? You Might Not Need All Those Tests Beforehand.
description: Cardiac stress tests, X-rays and other medical tests may not provide useful information before operations, and they could cause harm.
content: Let’s say you’re scheduled for a common and relatively low-risk operation, like a cataract removal, hernia repair or a hip or knee replacement. It’s normal to feel anxious about any upcoming surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: In Latest Twist in Philippine Politics, President to Run for Senate
description: Rodrigo Duterte entered the race days after his daughter announced her bid for vice president. He had previously said he would leave politics at the end of his term.
content: Rodrigo Duterte, the president of the Philippines, will run for Senate in next year’s elections, the secretary-general of Mr. Duterte’s political party said on Monday. The announcement was a reversal of Mr. Duterte’s previously stated plan to retire and came just days after Sara Duterte, his daughter, filed her papers to run for vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Got His Bipartisan Win. Now, Reality Sets In.
description: President Biden, who is facing low approval ratings, hopes the infrastructure bill will help him project sustained progress in confronting a surge in inflation and growing alarm about the midterm elections.
content: WASHINGTON — For more than an hour on Monday, President Biden enjoyed the kind of political moment he had eagerly sought and long promised, surrounded by a bipartisan cast of lawmakers on the South Lawn of the White House for the signing of landmark legislation forged through compromise at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: In Aaron Rodgers’s Return, Packers’ Championship Priorities Are Clear
description: Rodgers’s return from coronavirus isolation reinforced an N.F.L. axiom: The better the player, the more an organization is willing to endure.
content: GREEN BAY, Wis. — As he himself told the Pat McAfee Show last week, Aaron Rodgers is an athlete, not an activist. So after completing the mandatory 10-day isolation period that accompanied his contracting the coronavirus, Rodgers rejoined the Green Bay Packers and resumed doing what he does well, or best: playing football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Europe Toughens Rules for Unvaccinated as Fourth Covid Wave Swells
description: Austria took the hardest line yet on Monday, beginning a lockdown aimed exclusively at those who are not inoculated, part of a pattern to make life harder for resisters.
content: ROME — As temperatures drop and coronavirus infections spike across Europe, some countries are introducing increasingly targeted restrictions against the unvaccinated who are driving another wave of contagion and putting economic recoveries, public health and an eventual return to prepandemic freedoms at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
title: Two Journalists Arrested as India Cracks Down on Media
description: Faced with sectarian violence in the country’s northeast, the government has responded by disputing reports on the clashes and punishing those who covered them.
content: NEW DELHI — Two journalists in India were arrested after they went to cover religiously motivated violence in a northeastern state, the latest in a series of efforts to punish the media for news that casts the ruling Hindu nationalist party in a critical light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘The Sex Lives of College Girls’ Pursues an Awkward Education
description: The young stars of this new HBO Max comedy, cocreated by Mindy Kaling, discuss the mortification and messiness of undergraduate intimacy.
content: The title of “The Sex Lives of College Girls,” a new comedy that begins its first term Nov. 18 on HBO Max, is a work of clickbait-and-switch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 15, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 15, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: As Cuba Crushes Dissent, a Nationwide Protest Fizzles
description: In the days before the planned protest, the homes of government critics were surrounded by uniformed police officers, state security agents or government supporters holding picket signs, human rights activists said.
content: Demonstrators largely stayed off the streets of Cuba on Monday during what had been a highly anticipated nationwide march, with the police, state security agents and even civilians fanning across the country to prevent dissidents from leaving their houses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: U.S. Journalist Danny Fenster Is Freed From Myanmar Prison
description: The release was a rare positive development in the country, which has been torn by violence since a February coup.
content: Danny Fenster, an American journalist imprisoned for the past half-year by Myanmar’s junta, was freed Monday into the custody of Bill Richardson, the former U.S. diplomat who helped secure his freedom, and they left the country bound for the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The impact of COP26.
content: The U.N. global conference on climate change closed on Saturday in Glasgow with calls for countries to return next year with stronger emissions-reduction targets and promises to double the money available to help nations cope with the effects of global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Holiday Spectacular You Won’t Want to Miss
description: This steelhead trout gift assortment from Hudson Valley Fisheries will take you through the snacking season.
content: By the looks of it you’d think salmon, but it’s all steelhead. The large, pinkish orange-fleshed trout is farmed upstate by Hudson Valley Fisheries in Hudson, N.Y. For the holiday season the company has assembled a gift assortment with several iterations of the fish: cold-smoked “lox” style (four ounces) that’s not as salty as traditional New York lox; a richly succulent hot smoked fillet (eight ounces); and creamy rillettes (eight ounces) that benefit from the addition of a little sour cream. Moxie Ridge Farm’s Dream Cheese (eight ounces), a spreadable goat cheese; wheaty crackers; and a spreader are also included. It can be ordered through Dec. 28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Islanders Finally See the End of the Road
description: The team will play its first game at its new home, UBS Arena, on Saturday against Calgary, nearly six weeks after the N.H.L. season began.
content: The N.H.L. season has been underway for more than a month, and the Islanders have had more time in a Chicago restaurant than they did on their home ice. They spent more minutes in the penalty box in Winnipeg than they have in the locker room of their own arena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘All Too Well’ and the Weaponization of Memory
description: The new 10-minute version of a bitter breakup song from 2012 luxuriates in its details and its supersize length, correcting a power imbalance in the relationship it describes.
content: “A record label didn’t pick this song as a single,” Taylor Swift told an enraptured audience Friday afternoon in Manhattan, where a few hundred fans assembled for the debut of her latest self-directed music video: an elaborate clip for the new 10-minute version of “All Too Well,” a bitter remembrance of a past relationship that originally appeared on her 2012 album, “Red.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Let’s Talk About Latkes
description: The golden Hanukkah delights will be the subject of a discussion at the Temple Emanu-El Streicker Center on the Upper East Side.
content: A group of experts on Jewish food will toss around the subject of latkes at an in-person and virtual event at the Temple Emanu-El Streicker Center on Nov. 22. Gabriella Gershenson, a writer, will lead the discussion, joined by Jake Cohen and Leah Koenig, both cookbook authors; Sophie Rand, an owner of Luxe Latkes, a new food company; and Jeffrey Yoskowitz, a founder of Gefilteria. For those who attend in person, there will be samples to taste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Zachary Small
title: Thomas Jefferson Statue Evicted From City Hall Will Go to a Museum
description: Heeding requests to move the statue because of Jefferson’s legacy as an enslaver, the city approved a plan to relocate it to the New-York Historical Society.
content: A 19th-century statue of Thomas Jefferson, which had spent more than 100 years perched above the New York City Council chamber, was marked for removal last month by city officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden signs infrastructure bill, promoting benefits for Americans.
description: Billions of dollars will now pour into American communities, although the final package falls short of the president’s ambitions.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed a $1 trillion infrastructure bill into law on Monday afternoon, a bipartisan victory that will pour billions into the nation’s roads, ports and power lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Eric Lipton
title: Trump to Sell Marquee Washington Hotel for at Least $375 Million
description: The pending deal to sell the Trump International Hotel, often the subject of controversy during his presidency, comes after years of financial losses at the property.
content: Donald J. Trump’s family business has an agreement to sell its marquee Washington hotel, reaching a deal to fetch at least $375 million for a property that prompted ethical scrutiny and struggled to make money even as it drew steady crowds of lobbyists, lawmakers and Trump loyalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Supreme Court’s Growing Hostility to Arguments of Death Row Inmates
description: Recent rulings, including one turning down a death row inmate’s request supported by the prosecution, offer telling glimpses of the state of capital punishment.
content: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, on the same day it heard arguments about the future of abortion rights in Texas, the Supreme Court turned down an appeal from a federal prisoner facing execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Art of Botox
description: How facial muscle paralysis insinuated itself into our emotional and creative lives.
content: Last spring, Botox rolled out a series of ads directed by the filmmaker Errol Morris. Styled like very short documentary films, the ads featured Botox users — a widower, a single mother, a drag performer — telling touching, sad, ultimately redemptive anecdotes. In 2019, a typical Botox commercial pitched the product as a girlboss tonic that could infuse fantasy women with pluck as they slunk from boardroom to bar stool. Now it was being recast as a kind of truth serum, a tool of deep personal introspection. The mother gazed upon nostalgic photographs. The widower recalled his husband’s eyes and wept. Though the subjects did not mention Botox, the camera regarded their restful foreheads with sympathy and implied that the procedure had a profound therapeutic effect. The tagline was: “Still you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Wall St. Is Finally Getting Access to China. But for How Long?
description: Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are among those eyeing huge potential profits, undeterred by Beijing’s sudden policy changes and friction with the United States.
content: [Follow live updates on the upcoming meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s reliance on I.R.S. enforcement to pay for $1.85 trillion bill hits a snag.
description: The head of the Congressional Budget Office said on Monday that beefed-up tax enforcement would raise far less money than the White House projected.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pledge to fully pay for his $1.85 trillion social policy and climate spending package depends in large part on having a beefed-up Internal Revenue Service crack down on tax evaders, which the White House says will raise hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5 Episode 4: The Earth Moves
description: This season, Issa has undergone plenty of personal evolution, but some people still bring out her old self-doubt.
content: Nathan, Nathan, Nathan. There’s a lot we still don’t know about Nathan but we know that Issa likes him, or at least likes to keep him around. This week, the former and possibly future couple move past their emotional mix-up in the bedroom, from this season’s second episode, and head into new territory in more ways than one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Beto O’Rourke Announces Run for Texas Governor, Testing Democrats’ Strength
description: Mr. O’Rourke’s announcement on Monday set the stage for a pitched political showdown over the future of the country’s largest Republican-led state.
content: EAGLE PASS, Texas — Beto O’Rourke entered the race for Texas governor on Monday, criticizing what he described as the ultraconservative policies and anti-immigrant rhetoric of Gov. Greg Abbott. It is a long-shot bid to win an office Democrats last occupied in 1995.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: U.S. Covid upswing
content: Covid cases in the U.S. are starting to tick up again after plateauing at a high level following the Delta surge this summer. Conditions are slowly deteriorating in the West, Upper Midwest and the Northeast — and some experts are warning of a possible winter surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Democrats Still Don’t Understand Asian American Voters
description: Broad but shallow antiracism talk isn’t enough to hold on to Asian American support.
content: In the last edition of this newsletter, I wrote about the dilemma that faces progressives who may have problems with changes in education policies and curriculums but don’t want to feed into a nationwide anti-critical race theory panic. Today, I want to dig a bit deeper into that issue by examining how voters and politicians have responded to the fight over education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Forget Amazon. The Best Gifts Are Closer Than You Think.
description: It’s time to revive the tradition of puttering about in our favorite shops, looking for something that would make a loved one’s eyes light up.
content: NASHVILLE — When our children were younger and time alone together was harder to arrange, my husband and I would set aside a single day for our Christmas shopping. I hate shopping, but I loved those daylong dates. An entire day, alone with my husband, to choose surprises that would enchant the people we love best in the world!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Taxi Blast Outside U.K. Hospital Is Declared a Terrorist Act
description: Local leaders praised the driver as a hero, saying that he may have prevented a bigger calamity. He escaped the burning vehicle and locked the doors, trapping a passenger carrying explosives inside.
content: LONDON — The British police on Monday declared a blast in a taxi outside a Liverpool hospital a terrorist act after determining that it had been caused by an “improvised explosive device.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Twyla Tharp: ‘Each One of the Dances Is My Hope for a Perfect World’
description: In “Twyla Now,” a program of works featuring ballet stars and a youthful ensemble at New York City Center, Tharp merges the past with the present.
content: During the pandemic, Twyla Tharp did what most choreographers did: She worked on Zoom. A lot. “The whole time, I was wondering, well, when are we actually going to put bodies back into real places at real times?” she said in a recent interview. “And it was not possible until relatively very recently.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Halvah, Sufganiyot and Babka Chocolates for Hanukkah
description: Hanukkah Chic from Chocolat Moderne features eight filled chocolates with flavors of the season.
content: Along with Hanukkah gelt there are Hanukkah goodies. Chocolates with evocative fillings like coconut macaroon, halvah, raspberry sufganiyot and walnut babka are this year’s innovation from Chocolat Moderne in Chelsea. The decorated pieces come in a sleeve of eight ($29), one for each night of the holiday, and boxes of 12 ($49) and 24 ($79) pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Bottega Veneta Has a New Designer
description: Who is Matthieu Blazy, the newly appointed head of the Italian luxury house?
content: After the surprise announcement last week that the Bottega Veneta creative director Daniel Lee was leaving the Italian luxury house, a successor has been named: Matthieu Blazy, who may not be widely known outside of fashion (much like Mr. Lee when he took on the job in 2018) but is well regarded within the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Biden’s Child Care Plan Faces Resistance From Religious Groups
description: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, spurring a fight over who can benefit from President Biden’s landmark bill.
content: WASHINGTON — A coalition of conservative religious groups is waging an intensive lobbying effort to remove a nondiscrimination provision from President Biden’s ambitious prekindergarten and child care plans, fearing it would disqualify their programs from receiving a huge new infusion of federal money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: People Magazine Heads to New Ownership. Again.
description: Still a hit in print, the weekly chronicle of celebs and ordinary people who make news is set to become the property of a company specializing in informational websites.
content: People who read People magazine were treated last week to one of its most anticipated annual features: Sexiest Man Alive!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie-Helene Bertino
title: A Young Wife Becomes Pregnant — With an Owl
description: In Claire Oshetsky’s surrealistic debut, “Chouette,” motherhood presents an otherworldly dichotomy.
content: CHOUETTE By Claire Oshetsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 6 Teens Shot at Park in Aurora, Police Say
description: The injured, all students at Aurora Central High School in Colorado, were shot at nearby Nome Park. They range in age from 14 to 18.
content: Six teenagers were wounded in a drive-by shooting at a park in Aurora, Colo., on Monday afternoon that resulted in a nearby high school being placed under a lockdown, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Steven Erlanger
title: A Young Syrian Is Buried, as E.U. Foreign Ministers Meet on Belarus
description: A confrontation at the Polish-Belarusian border, a funeral for a dead Syrian boy trapped in between and a new round of E.U. sanctions mark the struggle with Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.
content: SOKOLKA, Poland — A few miles from here, in the small Polish town of Bohoniki, a young Syrian, Ahmed Al Hasan, was buried Monday. The 19-year-old man died in late October in a river in this freezing, forested buffer zone where thousands of migrants and asylum seekers have been sent by the Belarus government to try to break through into Poland and the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Credenzas
description: Whether you need a place to put the food and drinks on Thanksgiving or a platform for your TV, a credenza comes in handy.
content: A credenza is a multitalented piece of furniture. It can hold fine china or stereo components. It can serve as a platform for a television or a tray with bar supplies. It’s also a good place to put Thanksgiving platters piled high with food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New York City tells health providers to give booster shots to all adults who want them.
description: City officials asked health providers not to turn adults away, provided they met timing requirements, a move that comes as federal regulators consider expanding the eligibility pool for Pfizer-BioNTech’s booster.
content: New York City health officials on Monday encouraged all adults who want to receive coronavirus vaccine boosters to seek them out, and asked health providers not to turn them away, a move that comes as federal regulators consider expanding the eligibility pool for Pfizer-BioNTech’s booster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Pat Leahy, longest-serving member of Senate, will not run again.
description: At age 81, the Vermont Democrat has served in the chamber for nearly half a century.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and the chamber’s longest-serving member, announced on Monday that he would retire at the end of his term rather than seek re-election in 2022, closing out nearly half a century of service in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Alan Paller, a Mover on Cybersecurity Threat, Is Dead at 76
description: He made it his mission to find, recruit and develop the next generation of digital warriors to defend the nation against an onslaught of cyberattacks.
content: Alan Paller, a cybersecurity pioneer who devoted his life to improving the digital defense of the United States, died on Nov. 9 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork, in its first earnings report as a public company, shows more big losses.
description: The co-working business cut its expenses in the third quarter, but also showed a decline in revenue.
content: WeWork reported its first quarterly results as a public company on Monday, revealing that its co-working business is still racking up big losses and hemorrhaging cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Monopoly’s Bad Cousin
description: Companies use market power to suppress wages as well as to raise prices. The government is finally paying attention.
content: The nation’s antitrust police, asleep for the past few decades, barely opening their eyes to buzz through the latest corporate mergers, finally seem to be emerging from their slumber. That is a very good thing for the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Can Hydrogen Save Aviation’s Fuel Challenges? It’s Got a Way to Go.
description: Small, experimental hydrogen-powered planes are paving the way for net-zero carbon aviation by 2050. But the route is rocky.
content: A fully fueled Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner can fly roughly 8,000 miles while ferrying 300 or so passengers and their luggage. A battery with the energy equivalent to that fuel would weigh about 6.6 million pounds. That’s why — despite environmental advantages — we don’t have battery-powered electric airliners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, Mihir Zaveri and Ashley Wong
title: What the Infrastructure Bill Means for the New York Region
description: The bill, which President Biden is expected to sign Monday, is likely to fund road and bridge repairs, water infrastructure upgrades and airport expansions.
content: [Follow our live coverage of President Biden signing the infrastructure bill.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Dan Hinkel and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Lawyers Offer Dueling Narratives in Closing Arguments of Rittenhouse Trial
description: The jury will begin deliberating on Tuesday. The prosecution says Kyle Rittenhouse shot three men after instigating the shootings, while his lawyers say he was defending himself.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — A prosecutor in the Kyle Rittenhouse trial began his closing argument on Monday with an acknowledgment that the case had been clouded by politics, by feverish media coverage, by anger and outrage on both the right and the left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gregory and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Some U.S. states dangle cash and scholarships to get children vaccinated.
description: Programs incentivizing children ages 5 to 11 to get inoculated have proliferated since the C.D.C. recommended a coronavirus vaccine for them this month.
content: State governments in the United States are offering incentives for coronavirus shots for children, just as they did for adults earlier in the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samin Nosrat
title: How to Make Your Thanksgiving Dinner Less Boring
description: Samin Nosrat will say it: Every year, the meal is a lot of the same. Here are five ways she adds brightness, crunch, freshness and flavor.
content: Since my Iranian-immigrant mother spent my childhood resisting assimilation, I didn’t sit down to a proper Thanksgiving dinner until my early 20s. I like to think that I’m unburdened by all the nostalgic associations that cloud everyone else’s judgment of the meal. And so I’ll say what no one else will: It’s pretty boring on the palate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: No Surprises as Arozarena and India Win Rookie of the Year Awards
description: Tampa Bay’s Randy Arozarena and Cincinnati’s Jonathan India stood out in a deep rookie class for both leagues.
content: They came into this season with wildly different levels of major league experience, but outfielder Randy Arozarena of the Tampa Bay Rays and second baseman Jonathan India of the Cincinnati Reds are leaving it the same way, with each being named the winner of his league’s Rookie of the Year Award on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
title: Plagues Strike Egypt: Sudden Floods, Then 4-Inch Scorpions Called Deathstalkers
description: Swept from desert burrows, hundreds, if not thousands, of scorpions skittered into villages, stinging at least 503 people.
content: CAIRO — First came the lightning that strobe-lit the Nile skies a pale purply gray. What happened next checked all the boxes for a fierce storm: heavy rain, thunder and flash flooding that sent people scurrying for dry land and crumbled mud-brick houses around Aswan, the largest city in southern Egypt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: 9-Year-Old Boy Who Was Injured at Astroworld Festival Dies
description: Ezra Blount, who had been in a coma, became the 10th, and youngest, person to die from injuries sustained there.
content: A 9-year-old boy on Sunday became the 10th, and youngest, person to die from injuries sustained at the Astroworld festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Subway Fare Increase ‘Off the Table’ Thanks to Infrastructure Bill
description: Officials said that federal money, including the $1 trillion infrastructure bill, will help the M.T.A. keep fares stable for at least six months and avoid service cuts.
content: The transit agency that oversees New York City’s subway, buses and two regional commuter rails will postpone fare increases for at least six months and defer drastic service cuts now that it anticipates receiving billions of dollars from the federal infrastructure bill, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Women’s Tennis Stages a Fitting Finale to a Zany Year
description: Favorites who were virtually unknown a year ago. Big names missing in action. And, as usual, a championship completely up for grabs.
content: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — Karolina Pliskova let out a good long breath Sunday afternoon when she finally defeated Barbora Krejcikova to finish off her round-robin play at the WTA Finals Sunday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Heads to Africa as U.S. Tries to Avert Ethiopia Disaster
description: The conflict between rebels and the country’s government has already featured numerous alleged atrocities, and experts say it threatens the stability of all of East Africa.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken departed early Tuesday for a five-day swing to Africa, where he will lend support for democratic principles and seek to advance diplomacy aimed at preventing Ethiopia from descending into a catastrophic civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Republicans Gain Heavy House Edge in 2022 as Gerrymandered Maps Emerge
description: On a highly distorted congressional map that is still taking shape, the party has added enough safe House districts to capture control of the chamber based on its redistricting edge alone.
content: WASHINGTON — A year before the polls open in the 2022 midterm elections, Republicans are already poised to flip at least five seats in the closely divided House thanks to redrawn district maps that are more distorted, more disjointed and more gerrymandered than any since the Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Infrastructure, Rittenhouse, Bannon: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Preserved Lemon Has Heat
description: La Boîte’s new Tunisian-style lemons are a collaboration with Eric Ripert and Le Bon Magot.
content: Lior Lev Sercarz, the owner of the New York spice house La Boîte, has revamped that North African staple, preserved lemons, with the help of the chef Eric Ripert and Le Bon Magot, a maker of chutneys and condiments. Said to be Tunisian-style and based on a recipe from Mr. Sercarz’s grandfather, these lemons are notable because they are not just cured in salt, but also steeped in olive oil and bolstered with harissa, for uncommon richness. The slices are excellent on their own as a relish to serve with meats and seafood, and are particularly delicious alongside smoked fish; chop a few tablespoons to fold into sweet potato purée for Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: How College Sports May Change Under Proposed N.C.A.A. Rule Revisions
description: The notoriously bureaucratic N.C.A.A. is gearing up for debates about what it should look like going forward.
content: Nearly five months after a unanimous defeat at the Supreme Court, the N.C.A.A. will hold a special convention on Monday as it looks to rewrite its constitution and limit its legal risks in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Beginner’s Thanksgiving: 7 Recipes That Lighten the Workload
description: For first-time cooks, or anyone looking to simplify the holiday prep, this special menu minimizes effort and maximizes flavor.
content: For the fledgling cook, Thanksgiving dinner can seem like the most intimidating meal to make. It’s not often that a civilian is asked to knock out a long succession of dishes, including a giant bird, for a crowd with fixed ideas of how it should all be done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: How a Dispute Over Groceries Led to Artillery Strikes in Ukraine
description: In a sign of volatile East-West relations, a dispute over shopping in the Ukrainian conflict zone spiraled into fighting that sent war jitters rippling through Europe and the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Dr. Becky Doesn’t Think the Goal of Parenting Is to Make Your Kid Happy
description: “Because there are so many ways right now to get around frustration, you have to be mindful to raise kids who learn how to tolerate it.”
content: “Because there are so many ways right now to get around frustration, you have to be mindful to raise kids who learn how to tolerate it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib and Elisabeth Egan
title: Let’s Tackle Your Book Shopping List
description: There’s no doubt that books can make for the most heartfelt gifts — but choosing the perfect one can be nerve-racking. Let us help.
content: There’s no doubt that books can make for the most heartfelt gifts — but choosing the perfect one can be nerve-racking. Let us help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: What to Know About the Coronavirus in Pets
description: Scientists have developed vaccines for cats and dogs, but vaccinating companion animals is not necessary, experts say.
content: Scientists have developed vaccines for cats and dogs, but vaccinating companion animals is not necessary, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: These Afghan Students Found Refuge in Iraq
description: More than 100 students from the American University of Afghanistan fled the Taliban and are now studying in Iraq.
content: More than 100 students from the American University of Afghanistan fled the Taliban and are now studying in Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About St. Vincent and the Grenadines?
description: Can you find St. Vincent and the Grenadines on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with 110,000 people?
content: Can you find St. Vincent and the Grenadines on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with 110,000 people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.8 million in California
description: A storybook home in Oakland, a midcentury-modern house in Sierra Madre and a 1947 ranch-style retreat in Santa Cruz.
content: A storybook home in Oakland, a midcentury-modern house in Sierra Madre and a 1947 ranch-style retreat in Santa Cruz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Announces Plan to Block New Drilling Around Chaco Canyon
description: President Biden outlined on Monday new initiatives aimed at improving public safety, health, education and justice for Native Americans.
content: President Biden outlined on Monday new initiatives aimed at improving public safety, health, education and justice for Native Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Torrential Rains Batter British Columbia
description: The severe weather set off landslides in parts of the Canadian province, trapping dozens of vehicles and prompting evacuations in the region.
content: The severe weather set off landslides in parts of the Canadian province, trapping dozens of vehicles and prompting evacuations in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Court TV
title: Rittenhouse ‘Cannot Claim Self-Defense,’ Prosecutor Argues
description: Thomas Binger, the lead prosecutor in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial, said Mr. Rittenhouse lost the right to claim self-defense when he brought a military-style semiautomatic weapon to Kenosha, Wis., and created a dangerous situation.
content: Thomas Binger, the lead prosecutor in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial, said Mr. Rittenhouse lost the right to claim self-defense when he brought a military-style semiautomatic weapon to Kenosha, Wis., and created a dangerous situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: N.Y.C. Encourages All Adults to Seek Boosters
description: Dr. Dave A. Chokshi, New York City’s health commissioner, encouraged those 18 years or older who want to receive a Covid-19 booster to seek out the shot if they meet timing rules, and asked health care providers not to turn them away.
content: Dr. Dave A. Chokshi, New York City’s health commissioner, encouraged those 18 years or older who want to receive a Covid-19 booster to seek out the shot if they meet timing rules, and asked health care providers not to turn them away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Threats of Violence in Today’s Political Discourse
description: Readers discuss the rise in death threats and calls for bloodshed. Also: Senator Sinema; gerrymandered districts; immigration; Somalia.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Pleasures of Green Salad
description: Plenty of herbs and a dill vinaigrette make Eric Kim’s new recipe restaurant worthy.
content: Good morning. Eric Kim wrote about salad for The Times this week, and delivered a terrific recipe with the essay, for green salad with dill vinaigrette (above). That could be part of your meal tonight, maybe alongside some roasted salmon.
source.name: The New York Times
